extends GVRTexture

      • GVRBitmapTexture

        public GVRBitmapTexture(GVRContext gvrContext,
                        int width,
                        int height,
                        byte[] grayscaleData)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Create a new, grayscale texture, from an array of luminance bytes.
        Parameters:
        gvrContext - Current GVRContext
        width - Texture width, in pixels
        height - Texture height, in pixels
        grayscaleData - width * height bytes of gray scale data
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If width or height is <= 0, or if grayScaleData is null, or if grayscaleData.length < height * width
        Since:
        1.6.3

    • Method Detail

      • update

        public boolean update(int width,
                      int height,
                      byte[] grayscaleData)
               throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Copy new luminance data to a grayscale texture. Creating a new GVRTexture is pretty cheap, but it's still not a totally trivial operation: it does involve some memory management and some GL hardware handshaking. Reusing the texture reduces this overhead (primarily by delaying garbage collection). Do be aware that updating a texture will affect any and all materials (and/or post effects) that use the texture!
        Parameters:
        width - Texture width, in pixels
        height - Texture height, in pixels
        grayscaleData - width * height bytes of gray scale data
        Returns:
        true if the update succeeded, and false if it failed. Updating a texture requires that the bitmap parameter has the exact same size and bit depth as the original bitmap. In particular, you can't update a 'normal' 32-bit texture with grayscale data!
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If width or height is <= 0, or if grayScaleData is null, or if grayscaleData.length < height * width
        Since:
        1.6.3

      • update

        public boolean update(Bitmap bitmap)
        Copy a new Bitmap to the GL texture. Creating a new GVRTexture is pretty cheap, but it's still not a totally trivial operation: it does involve some memory management and some GL hardware handshaking. Reusing the texture reduces this overhead (primarily by delaying garbage collection). Do be aware that updating a texture will affect any and all materials (and/or post effects) that use the texture!
        Parameters:
        bitmap - A standard Android Bitmap
        Returns:
        true if the update succeeded, and false if it failed. Updating a texture requires that the bitmap parameter has the exact same size and bit depth as the original bitmap. In particular, you can't update a grayscale texture with 'normal' 32-bit data!
        Since:
        1.6.3
